items.content_html:
Summary

 
My PhD research explores how museums worldwide leverage Human-Centred Design (HCD) to address their digital collection challenges by incorporating stakeholder input and user engagement. By examining the systems and collaborative process that support HCD implementation and its interactions with institutional, cultural, and technological factors, it aims to provide insights into the diverse paths for digitalising museum collections.

Challenges

Many regions lack long-term strategies to promote the growth of digital transformation in museums. Most museums struggle with finding the right collaborators (e.g. technology providers, stakeholders, collection specialists) and ensuring sustainable digital product development.

Goals

The research answers three questions:

  • What strategies, roles, resources, and infrastructures are required for HCD-based collection digitalisation? 
  • What cultural, technological, and institutional factors impact design decisions in the projects?

Mixed Methods

Semi-structured interviews: I conducted 17 in-depth interviews with participants working on various aspects (e.g. UI/UX design, PM, CMS, AI engineering, curation, etc.) of digitalisation projects worldwide. 

Survey: A 21-item survey was designed to validate themes derived from interviews. I am currently collecting responses from the survey.

Tools: Atlas.ti; Qualtrics; Kumu; Figma

Key Insights

My research revealed:

  • Institutional enablers and barriers to practice HCD-based digitalisation
  • Three types of collaboration approaches in developing digital infrastructures
  • Pathways to successful skill sharing and knowledge exchange in design process
  • Effective experimental and iteration methods to achieve collective innovation
  • The importance of governmental guidance in directing the general goal of digitalisation 

I am currently developing a System Map of collection digitalisation using kumu.io. It will show the interdependence between various factors and actors related to human-centred approach in technology integration.

items.content_html:
Summary

A 4-week research project that developed practical guidance for cultural organisation workers to engage in social media activism, addressing challenges such as misinformation, hate speech, and censorship.

Role

  • Rapid review
  • Workshop facilitation
  • Qualitative analysis

Challenges

The culture sector faces an urgent need to provide guidance on engaging in meaningful online activism while ensuring individual safety, institutional integrity, and compliance with regulations like the controversial Online Safety Bill draft developed in 2021.

Goals

The research answered these questions:

  • How do museum professionals experience risks and rewards of engaging in activism on social media? How do they ensure online safety?
  • What responsibilities do institutions and sectors have in addressing these issues?

Methods

Rapid literature review: I led a rapid review of current sectoral and organisational policy on social media use. 

Focus group workshops: 7 cultural organisation professionals and 6 cross-disciplinary researchers were recruited for co-creation activities in 2 online workshops:

  • Workshop 1: To brainstorm with cultural organisation workers to identify pain points in their social media engagement
  • Workshop 2: To lead researchers explore solutions to these challenges and risks

Triangulation: Key themes extracted from the interviews were triangulated with rapid review findings, and analysed in the report.

Key Insights

  • There has been no systematic support to help museum professionals to reflect on the risks and rewards of using social media at work.
  • Benefits of social media engagement: improving inclusivity and accessibility, promoting workers’ career profile, and building mutual trust between museums and communities. 
  • Harms of social media engagement:
    • Self-censorship: Feeling the need to suppress cultural workers' own opinions or ideas due to fear of public backlash.
    • Mental health issues: Experiencing stress, anxiety, or other mental health challenges, such as cyberbullying or negative online interactions.
    • Blurring of institutional and individual boundaries: Difficulty separating personal views from those of the cultural organisation, leading to potential conflicts or misunderstandings.

items.title: Design Heuristics: FeelTheArt®
items.summary: Summary FeelTheArt is a mobile application designed to enable users to create augmented exhibitions and virtual galleries with artworks from famous museums.
items.content_html:
Summary

FeelTheArt is a mobile application designed to enable users to create augmented exhibitions and virtual galleries with artworks from famous museums.

Role

  • Heuristic analysis

Methods

Heuristics development
Evaluate the experience and identify x usability issues 
 
As a UX researcher, I conducted a systematic evaluation of FeelTheArt Beta using
selected heuristics. I thoroughly examined each heuristic in relation to the use flow, landing page, interaction design in gallery curation, and self-guided navigation. I documented any violations or areas where the app could be optimised. I prioritised the identified issues in the evaluation report according to their impact on usability and user experience.
 

Impact

Livedeo updated the Beta version of FeelTheArt based on my suggestions. The application has been able to add a new landing page to offer more effective guidance, and links were added to the audio guide interface for users to explore how other people curated with the artwork. Editor selected galleries and content were placed on the top of all user-generated galleries to highlight themes of the artworks.

items.title: Strategy Development for Research & Innovation
items.summary: Project Summary The Institute for Digital Culture is a pioneering research centre in helping cultural sectors adapt to digital transformation. They planned to establish research hubs in different regions. I acted as a research assistant to pilot a study that paved the way for the…
items.content_html:
Project Summary

The Institute for Digital Culture is a pioneering research centre in helping cultural sectors adapt to digital transformation. They planned to establish research hubs in different regions. I acted as a research assistant to pilot a study that paved the way for the first hub, the "Digital Culture Observatory". It reviewed existing research strategies on digital activities in cultural institutions, and envisioned a series of future-oriented policies and strategies.

Goal

To review the current landscape of cross-sectoral and cross-institutional research collaborations within cultural institutions. As one of the Institute's first research projects with their partners, the goal is to pave the way for establishing the Observatory - a research hub dedicated to digital culture in Australia.

My Role
  • Strategic analysis & development
  • Literature review 

Methods

Scoping Review

I led a review of research strategies related to technology R&D in 30+ cultural institutions, examining their outputs and impact. Using insights garnered from this exploration, the team formulated practical guidelines for both practice and action research tailored to cultural institutions in Australia.

Key Insights

Based on the scoping review, I developed a taxonomy of human-centred research strategies:

  • Practice-based Research fosters co-creation and experimentation in museums.
  • Applied Research uses evidence-informed evaluation to drive the development of impactful solutions, creating tangible benefits for individuals and communities in the long term.
  • Participatory Research promotes community engagement and social change. It is the fundation of human-centred research .
  • Innovative Research Translation challenges conventional research strategies. Using multisensory technologies as creative mediums, it expands the accessibility and reach of research outcomes.

Impact 

The research supported Monash University and the Australian National University in curating a seminar series that built digital research capacity. It initiated partnerships between the Institute for Digital Culture and Australian cultural sectors.

items.title: About Me
items.summary: 👋 Hi, I am Han. I research and design the human side of digital transformation. When I was a curator intern, I uncovered a lot of biased legacy data in the collection database. I created the first spreadsheet at that museum to survey these entries.
items.content_html:
👋 Hi, I am Han. I research and design the human side of digital transformation.

When I was a curator intern, I uncovered a lot of biased legacy data in the collection database. I created the first spreadsheet at that museum to survey these entries. I translated it into an inclusive research guideline that changed the way other staff used sensitive data. 

This is what I do: I design systems to get people embracing positive change.

I started my PhD when "AI" and "Web 3" became buzzwords. Industries rapidly adopted these technological solutions without considering their implications. These include organisations with traditional business models, where implementing new technology is often considered “challenging”. So far, I have interviewed 9 organisations to identify their challenges. I am developing a workbook that enhances organisational learning on implications and requirements for digital transformation, and to help them make informed decisions that drive success. 

My experience in cultural & creative industries taught me to be people-centred. In 2023, I brought 2 award-winning cultural education apps to life, making art accessible to people with diverse cognition needs. I streamlined innovative workflows in UX teams, integrating gen-AI tools in persona research and prototyping.

I lead research to inform decision making. When I worked as a research assistant, I identified research centre's needs for expanded digital inclusion and strategic collaboration, helping it establish effective partnerships with international stakeholders.

I use interviews, surveys, contextual inquiry, and textual analysis to understand how human beings make meanings in systems around them. I only conduct research when it creates solutions that have social impact. I know how to work with product experts, engineers, and data scientists.

I advocate for digital infrastructure to be collaborative, beyond organisational or national silos. I have lectured at universities and conferences worldwide to help people discover opportunities for collaboration and catalysts for change. 

I love experiments, trust-building, and exchange - they empower us to better dwell in this world.

You can view my full CV on LinkedIn.

items.title: Transnational Education Partnerships
items.summary: Project Summary The School of Museum Studies is the leading curatorial research centre in the UK. They want to expand their partnerships with universities in Asia. This project is a pilot study to understand how education partnerships form between universities and cultural organisations in Western…
items.content_html:
Project Summary

The School of Museum Studies is the leading curatorial research centre in the UK. They want to expand their partnerships with universities in Asia. This project is a pilot study to understand how education partnerships form between universities and cultural organisations in Western and developing countries. I analysed how transnational curatorial education develop within emerging cultural centres, particularly in China, Qatar, and Saudi Arabia. 

Goal

Map out the landscape of transnational education in 3 months of project cycle. Develop a report that offers adivce on partnership research and development.

My Role
  • In-depth interviews & analysis
  • Policy research
  • Report writing 

Methods

Policy Review

I started by developing a spreadsheet covering current higher education programmes about museums and heritage at branch campuses of Western universities. I analysed institutional policy documents relating to their partners and course development.

Semi-structured Interview

From 30 education programmes analysed, I identified 7 case studies and conducted 8 semi-structured interviews with selected participants. This informed strategies for their future partnership-building.

Key Insights

  • Three types of transnational partnerships identified: branch campus, joint degree programmes, and professional training programmes.
  • Transnational education strengthened partnerships between universities, as well as between universities and local museums.
  • Local organisations had limited ownership of education programmes because most of the curriculum development was led by the Western institutions.
  • The pandemic, miscommunications, and different organisational cultures and policies posed significant challenges in partnership management.

Impact

We delivered a report that presented the landscape of transnational collaborations between universities, governments and cultural organisations in China and the Middle East.

Our report was featuerd in a panel discussion at the Anthropology and Education Conference 2024 (Royal Anthropological Institute, London). Our findings secured a funding for future development of the project.
